危机是一件美妙的事情。只有当谚语中的便便击中扇子时，我们才意识到我们对世界的信念并不像我们想象的那样健全。信仰，其核心，仅仅是如何对特定情况作出反应的模型。当我们第一次拾起一种信念时，它就像是一本指导手册：“如果你遇到了X，就去做Y”。然而，随着时间的推移，信念在我们心中变得如此根深蒂固，以至于我们忘记了它们应该只是路线图。直到有一天我们意识到地形已经改变，地图不再工作。
在过去的几年里，我开始意识到这一点，因为我在当时认为合理的逻辑基础上，在我的职业生涯中做了几次转变。我对自己和这个世界有某些(错误的)认知，并做出了一些相应的决定。至少可以说，这些决定中的大多数都没有像我希望的那样实现，我只能寻找答案。当我开始阐述我的假设时，我得出了一个有力但令人不安的结论：我正在自动驾驶的生活中前进，受到已经过期的信念的驱使。我打破陈规的任何希望都在于重新定义什么是真的。
亲爱的读者，这就是我最终为自己定义这七个严酷事实的原因。事后看来，我经历的所有低谷都是一种变相的祝福，因为它们最终放大了那些让我偏离真正想要的东西的病态假设。现在我与你分享这一苦药，希望它能治愈你任何阻碍你前进的东西。振作起来，因为这不会轻而易举地过去。
我们都相信，没有其他人拥有我们拥有的才华、思想和怪癖的独特组合。我们觉得，我们自己的行为背后总是有合理的逻辑，而其他人的行为主要是由他们的冲动驱动的。即使你和其他人一样工作，看同样的节目，阅读同样的书，度过同样的假期，你仍然有让你完全与众不同的怪癖：比如你的讽刺，或者你把袜子和衬衫缝搭配的方式。你也是胡说八道。
你觉得这是珍贵的，因为只有你，而不是其他人，能接触到你病态的、扭曲的心灵。你醒着的每一分钟都生活在你的思想和情感中，这就是为什么没有人能像你这样了解你。但你猜怎么着？其他人和你有类似的想法，就他们而言，他们，而不是你，是宇宙的中心。这样，我们所有人都比我们愿意承认的更相似，即使我们不想被视为一个大的、同质的群体的一部分。事实是，除非你是成吉思汗，否则你只是千百万人中的一个。
也就是说，这一事实导致了两个令人信服的认识。首先，如果你试一试，你实际上可以和别人相处得更好，因为你和他们有比你愿意承认的更多的共同点。因此，不要把注意力集中在细微的不同上，而要处理你有的更大的相似之处。其次，通过更好地了解自己，你也可以了解他人。这可能会产生各种各样的好结果。你不仅可以更好地与他人相处，还可以找到新的机会。你有那个奇怪的爱好吗？也许，还有其他人也喜欢这样，你可以把它变成生意吗？毕竟，你只需要1000个真正的粉丝。所以别再当天后了，拥抱你的同一性吧。
鉴于我们认为自己处于宇宙的中心，我们期望世界以我们期望的方式对我们的努力和个性做出回应。仅仅因为我们对某事充满热情，或者努力工作去创造某事，并不意味着这个世界就会“领会”它。人们只关心你将如何帮助他们，而不是你是一个多好的人。
如果你想让人们在乎，那就开始从他们的角度去思考吧。我从自己的写作经验中知道，如果不是读者想读的东西，我的想法的质量或我的语言的正确性一点也不重要。直到最近，我才明白著名作家史蒂文·普雷斯菲尔德(Steven Pressfield)给他的一本书取名背后的含义：
这并不是要让你失望，也不是要侵蚀你对人们善良的信仰。相反，它是为了帮助你认识到，和你一样，每个人都有自己的恐惧、希望和不安全感需要应对。你投入到这个世界上的任何东西都会在这个背景下进行评估。所以培养一些同理心，把你的头从沙子里拿出来。问问你自己：我给世界提供了什么？
需要说明的是，没有什么可以代替努力工作。你越努力，成功的机会就越大。像“幸运眷顾勇者”这样的谚语理所当然地激励我们为自己的成功承担责任。但他们内心有一个潜台词并不总是很明显：如果你失败了，很可能是你自己的错。
如果你已经生活了一段时间，你就会知道，有时候，尽管你全力以赴，但事情就是不像你想的那样。这就是宇宙的秩序。对于任何特定的结果，都必须有很多变量对齐，而不是所有的变量都在你的控制之下。你所能做的就是日复一日地遵循这个过程，因为这样做会增加你最终达到目标的几率。记住，你总是可以按照你自己的方式倾斜概率，但永远不能保证一个具体的结果。
那么你应该怎么做呢？正如唐·米格尔·鲁伊斯(Don Miguel Ruiz)在他的书“四个协议”(The Four Agreement)中所说，答案非常简单：
这个看似简单的建议背后的真正含义是建立在自我同情的基础上的。当你知道你已经付出了你的全部时，你承诺会更善待未来的自己。你接受只有你的行为在你的控制之下。尽你最大的努力，让它过去吧。
动力真的很棒，不是吗？无论是观看一场著名的毕业典礼演讲，还是阅读一本关于如何利用你未实现的潜力的畅销书，动机都会让古老的多巴胺像洪水一样流淌。唯一的障碍是什么？这种兴奋永远不会持续。不知不觉中，你又回到了原来的自己，一边哀叹自己什么都做不了，一边渴望另一剂鼓舞人心的东西。当谈到达到你想要的结果时，动机是没有机会的，因为它面对的是一个强大的对手：习惯。
令人痛苦的事实是，除非你们的习惯朝着同一个方向一致，否则再多的动力也不能引导你实现目标。你的大脑只是不允许这样做，因为它习惯了以某种方式做事，并且已经建立了支持这些行为的线路。这就是为什么在你希望实现一个大目标之前，你必须成为那种实现这些目标的人。我们的朋友亚里士多德在两千多年前说的这句话是完全正确的：
呆伯特的创建者斯科特·亚当斯(Scott Adams)通过他的系统与目标框架提出了一种让人养成正确习惯的实用方法。在这种方法中，重点不是未来的目标，而是尽职尽责地遵循最终将你带到那里的过程。制度不是一种战略，而是一种生活方式。你继续每天锻炼，不是因为你想在海滩度假时拥有洗衣板腹肌，而是因为你是那种保持身材的人。一旦你实现了目标，它们就会失去力量。系统会永远改变你的行为。
大多数人声称，如果他们找到了自己的激情，他们会更快乐。逻辑通常是这样的：如果你找到了你的激情，工作就不会感觉像是工作，你会因为做你喜欢的事情而得到报酬！好吧，这里有个坏消息：激情的整个概念都是富人和成功人士撒的谎。激情不是在任务结束时等待你的圣杯。更有可能的是，它现在阻碍了你做任何有价值的事情。
问问自己：你是在寻找一项你会为了自己而做的耗费精力的活动(激情的真正定义)，还是只想超越你目前的成功水平(名气和/或金钱)，做一些不像你的工作那样让人灵魂崩溃的事情？大多数人都乐于满足于第二种情况，去他妈的激情吧。弄清楚你想要什么，这样你对激情的追求就不会成为延长你目前舒适状态的借口。
简单的事实是：你通过真正擅长你已经知道的事情来创造你自己的激情。你对任何追求的热情都与你用它取得的成功直接相关。如果你不停地大量生产一幅又一幅画，或者一款又一款没人关心的应用程序，你的热情会比自来水中的阿司匹林更快消退。在你已经做的事情上发展你的技能，并成为最好的。因为一旦金钱和荣誉开始滚滚而来，激情就会自动产生。
时局艰难。你有责任。你需要经验。你需要钱。所以你要等着迈出第一步。然后你会变老，有更多的经验和金钱。但是你的责任也膨胀了。你要供一两个孩子上学；你要为大房子和汽车分期付款，还有每年的假期。所以你就等着…。
听起来耳熟吗？我们的连线方式，我们的大多数行为都是建立在避免痛苦的基础上的，无论是真实的还是感知的。我们的默认取向是逃离不想要的东西，而不是伸手去追求它。恐惧是一种无处不在的感觉，一种来自我们进化历史的礼物，在那里，过于无所畏惧可能会将你从基因库中抹去。丛林的危险现在消失了，但恐惧依然存在，让我们在想要打破模式时犹豫不决。然而，正如塞涅卡所说：
人类是有弹性的。我们有从不可能的解决方案中找到出路的诀窍。即使是早产儿也有抗争和生存的意愿。但我们忘记了这一点，不相信我们找到办法的能力。所以我们在不安的舒适中呆在原地。不知道我们正在让自己陷入悔恨，这是人类感受到的最压抑的情绪之一。当人们在临终之时，他们不会后悔他们所做的事情。不是的。他们后悔自己没有做的事。那就振作起来吧。冒一点险吧。即使不成功，你也会在这里。
人们在生活中的地位取决于他们的环境、他们的能力、他们投入的工作和纯粹的愚蠢的运气。当你拿自己和别人比较时，你是不理性的。为什么？因为除非所有的变量对你和他们来说都是完全相同的，否则比较是没有根据的。即使是在同一所房子里出生和长大的双胞胎也不会有相同的结局。世界上有太多的随机性，以及我们个人如何对完全相同的条件做出反应。所以，即使你做的每件事都是“正确的”，仍然会有比你更好的结果的人。事情就是这样。你怎么能忍受这个残酷的事实呢？
心理学家乔丹·彼得森(Jordan Peterson)在他的书“生活的12条规则”(12 Rules For Life)中最好地阐述了前进的道路：
“把自己和昨天的自己相比，而不是和今天的别人相比。”
还要记住，你只能看到别人生命中的一小部分。你只看到财富；你看不到痛苦、功能失调或不安全感。我们倾向于将别人最好的部分与我们生活的平均水平进行比较。难怪Instagram让我们感觉如此糟糕。要知道，你能控制的只有两件事，一是你为自己设定的远景，二是你为实现远景而采取的行动。如果你不喜欢你今天所处的位置，专注于内心。每天都会变得更好，哪怕只是一点点。别再玩别人的游戏了。做最好的自己。
note_en:
A crisis is a wonderful thing. It is only when the proverbial poop hits the fan, that we realize our beliefs about the world are not as sound as we thought. A belief, at its core, is simply a model of how to react to a specific situation. When we first pick up a belief, its something like an instruction manual: ‘if you encounter X, do Y’. Over time, however, beliefs become so ingrained within us that we forget they are just supposed to be roadmaps. Until one day we realize that the terrain has changed and the maps no longer work.
 I began realizing this over the last few years as I made a few transitions in my career based on what I thought was sound logic at that time. I had certain (mis)perceptions about myself and the world, and took a few decisions accordingly. To say the least, most of these decisions didn’t pan out as I hoped and I was left searching for answers. As I began articulating my assumptions, I came to a powerful, but unnerving conclusion: I was moving through life on auto-pilot, driven by beliefs that were past their expiry date. Any hope I had of breaking the rut lay in redefining what was true.
 And that, dear reader, is how I ended up defining these seven harsh truths for myself. In hindsight, all the lows I experienced were a blessing in disguise because they ended up magnifying the ill-formed assumptions that were leading me away from what I truly wanted. Now I’m sharing this bitter medicine with you, hoping it could cure you of whatever is holding you back. Brace yourselves, because this will not go down easy.
  We all believe that no one else possesses the unique mix of talents, thoughts and quirks that we have. Our own actions, we feel, always have sound logic behind them while others are driven mainly by their impulses. Even if you work in a job like the rest of them, watch the same shows, read the same books, and take the same vacations, you still have your quirks that set you totally apart: like your sarcasm, or the way you match your socks with the seam of your shirt. You are also full of BS.
 You feel this precious because only you, and no one else, has access to your sick, twisted mind. You live with your thoughts and emotions every waking minute and that’s why no one else can know you as well as you do. But guess what? Others have minds similar to yours and as far as they are concerned, they, not you, are at the center of the universe. This way, all of us are more alike than we care to admit even if we don’t want to be seen as part of a large, homogenous group. Truth is, unless you are Genghis Khan, you  are just one among millions.
  That said, this fact leads to two empowering realizations. First, if you just try, you can actually get along better with others because you have more in common with them than you care to admit. So stop focusing on minor differences and work with the larger similarities you have. Second, by knowing yourself better, you can know others as well. This can have all sorts of good consequences. Not only will you get along better with others, but you can also find new opportunities. That weird hobby you have? Maybe, there are other people who like that too and you can turn it into a business? After all, you only need a  1,000 true fans. So stop being such a diva and embrace your sameness.
  Given we see ourselves at the centre of our universe, we expect the world to respond to our efforts and personality in ways that we expect it to. Just because we are deeply passionate about something, or have worked really hard to create something doesn’t mean the world will ‘get’ it. People only care about how you will help them; not how good a person you are.
  If you want people to give a damn, start thinking from their point of view. I know from my own experience writing that the quality of my ideas or the correctness of my language doesn’t matter a bit if it’s not what readers want to read. Only recently have I understood the meaning behind what Steven Pressfield, the famous author titled one of his books:
  This is not meant to be bring you down or erode your faith in the goodness of people. Rather, it’s to help you realize that like you, everyone has their own fears, hopes and insecurities to deal with. Anything you put out into the world will be evaluated within that context. So develop some empathy and get your head out of the sand. Ask yourself: What am I offering to the world?
  To be clear, there is no substitute for hard work. The harder you grind, the higher your chances of success. Adages like ‘fortune favours the brave’ rightfully goad us into taking responsibility for our success. But there is a subtext within them that isn’t always apparent: if you fail, its probably your own fault.
 If you’ve been around for a while you know that sometimes despite giving it your all, things just don’t go your way. That is just how the universe is ordered. For any specific outcome to happen a lot of variables have to align, not all of them in your control. All you can do is follow the process, day in and day out, because doing so improves your odds of reaching your goal eventually. Remember that you can always tilt the probabilities your way, but can never guarantee a specific outcome.
  So what should you do? As Don Miguel Ruiz says in his book ‘The Four Agreements’, the answer is childishly simple:
  The real meaning behind this deceptively simple advice is based on self-compassion. When you know you have given your all, you promise to treat your future self more kindly. You accept that only your actions are in your control. Do your best and let it go.
  Motivation feels really good, doesn’t it? Whether it’s watching a famous commencement speech, or reading a bestseller on how to utilize your unfulfilled potential, motivation gets the old dopamine flowing like flooded river. The only hitch? This high never lasts. Before you know it, you are back to your old self, craving another dose of that inspiring stuff as you bemoan your inability to get anything done. When it comes to achieving the results you want, motivation stands no chance because it is up against a formidable opponent: habit.
 The painful fact is that no amount of motivation can lead you to your goals unless your habits are aligned in the same direction. Your brain just won’t allow it because it is used to doing things a certain way and has set up its wiring to support those behaviours. That is why  before you can hope to achieve a big goal, you have to become the sort of person who achieves those sorts of goals. Our friend Aristotle had it absolutely right when he said this more than two thousand years ago:
   A practical way to enable the right habits comes from Dilbert creator Scott Adams, through his systems vs goals framework. In this approach, the focus is not on a future goal but on dutifully following processes that will eventually lead you there. Systems are not a strategy; they are a way of life. You continue to exercise daily not because you want washboard abs for a beach holiday, but because you are the kind of person who stays in shape. Goals lose their power once you achieve them. Systems change your behaviour for good.
  Most people claim they would be happier if they found their passion. The logic usually goes like this: if you found your passion, work will not feel like work and you will get paid for doing the thing you love! Well, here’s the bad news: the whole concept of passion is a lie told by the rich and the successful. Passion is not the holy grail waiting for you at the end of a quest. More likely, it is holding you back from getting anything worthwhile done right now.
 Ask yourself: are you looking for an all-consuming activity that you would do for its own sake (true definition of passion) Or do you just want to exceed your current level of success (fame and/or money) doing something that is not as soul-crushing as your job? Most people would happily settle for the second, passion be damned. Be clear on what you want, so that your quest for passion doesn’t become an excuse for prolonging your current state of comfort.
  The simple fact is this: you create your own passion by getting really good at something you  already know. Your enthusiasm for any pursuit is directly correlated to the success you achieve with it. If you keep churning out painting after painting, or app after app that no one cares about, your passion will fizzle out faster than aspirin in tap water. Develop your skills in something you already do and become the best at it. Because once the money and accolades start rolling in, passion will take care of itself.
  Times are tough. You have responsibilities. You need experience. You need the money. So you wait to take the first step. Then you get older, and have more experience and money. But your responsibilities have ballooned as well. You’re putting a kid or two through school; you pay installments on the big house and car, plus there are the annual vacations. So you wait…
 Sounds familiar? The way we’re wired, most of our behaviors are based on avoidance of pain, real or perceived. Our default orientation is to run away from what is not desirable, rather than reach out for what is. Fear is an ever-present sensation, a gift from our evolutionary past where being too fearless could wipe you out from the gene pool. The dangers of the jungle are now gone, but the fear still remains, making us hesitate whenever we want to break out of the mold. However, as Seneca said:
   Humans are resilient. We have a knack of finding a way out of impossible solutions. Even a premature baby has a will to fight and survive. But we forget this and mistrust our ability to find a way. So we stay put in uneasy comfort. Not knowing that we are setting ourselves for regret, one of the most crushing emotions human feel. When people are on their deathbeds, they don’t regret the things they did. No. They regret what they  did not do. So shake thing up. Risk it a little. Even if it doesn’t work out, you will still be here.
  Where people are in their lives is a function of their circumstances, their aptitude, the work they put in and plain dumb luck. When you compare yourself to others, you are being irrational. Why? Because unless all the variables are exactly the same for you and them, the comparison is baseless. Not even twins born and raised in the same house end up the same. There is just too much randomness in the world and how we individually react to the exact same conditions. So even if you do everything ‘right’, there will still be people who end up with better outcomes than you. That is just how it is. How do you live with this bitter truth?
 The way forward has been best articulated by psychologist Jordan Peterson in his book 12 Rules for Life:
 ‘Compare yourself with who you were yesterday, not with who someone else is today.’
  Also remember that you only see a sliver of other people’s lives. You only see the wealth; you don’t see the pain, dysfunction or insecurities. We tend to compare others’ best bits with the  average of our lives. No wonder Instagram makes us feel so bad. Understand that the only two things you can control are the vision you set for yourself, and the actions you take to achieve it. If you don’t like where you are today, focus inward. Get better everyday, even if a little bit. Stop playing someone else’s game. Become the best at your own.

NIM是一种编程语言，其语法类似于Python，但被编译为二进制代码。
NIM比Python快得多(当然，在比较为Python包装的C库时不是这样)。NIM代码首先编译成C，然后编译成二进制文件，总是有可能获得类似C的性能。
NIM有一个强类型系统，这与Python不同，在Python中只能选择性地指定类型。类型化语言为编译器提供更好的信息，以便进行更好的优化。
内存泄漏不是问题，因为NIM使用几个可用的垃圾收集器中的一个。新的ARC选项使用引用计数而不是GC。
NIM的采用率很低，但这可能是因为1.0版需要很长时间才能发布。NIM现已于2019年9月发布，为应用程序和库的构建奠定了良好的基础。
尼姆有充分的理由使用它，但也有一些缺点。未来几年，这些情况可能会有所改善。
NIM的追随者很少，这意味着可用的工作很少，而且NIM的库和框架也很缺乏。但是，可以利用C、C++和Python库，帮助弥合差距。
NIM支持线程、通道和异步。然而，一般来说，并发/并行需要做更多的工作。相关文章：概述NIM的并发/并行特性的当前状态。
由于开发良好的Web框架，许多语言变得流行起来(例如，Ruby有Rails，Elixir有Phoenix，Crystal有Amber、Lucky等)。NIM拥有Jester，它仍然需要进一步的开发和文档。还有Karax，这是一个SPA Web框架。
note_en:
Nim is a programming language that has a syntax similar to Python but is compiled to binary code.
     Nim is much faster than Python (not when comparing C libraries wrapped for Python of course). Nim code compiles first to C then to binaries, with C-like performance always a possibility.
  Nim has a strong type system, unlike Python where types can only be specified optionally. A typed language gives better information to the compiler for better optimizations.
  Memory leaks are not a concern as Nim uses one of several available garbage collectors. The new ARC option works with reference counting instead of a GC.
    Nim has seen low levels of adoption, but this may be due to version 1.0 taking a long time to be released. Now released in September 2019 Nim has a good foundation for applications and libraries to build on.
 Nim has  good reasons to use it, but also has some disadvantages. These are likely to improve over the next few years.
    Nim has a small following, which means few jobs are available, and the libraries and frameworks for Nim are lacking. C, C++ and Python libraries can be utilized, however, helping to bridge the gap.
  Nim supports threads, channels and async. However in general concurrency/parallelism needs more work. Related article:  an overview of the current state of Nim’s concurrency/parallelism features.
    Many languages became popular due to well developed web frameworks (e.g. Ruby has Rails, Elixir has Phoenix and Crystal has Amber, Lucky and others). Nim has  Jester which still needs further development and documentation. There is also  Karax which is a SPA web framework.

树莓派4号已经快一岁了，这是忙碌的一年。我们已经售出了近300万台，出货了几个小的主板版本，并将2 GB版本的价格从45美元降到了35美元。在软件方面，我们已经做了大量的工作来降低设备的空闲和负载功耗，通过了OpenGL ES 3.1标准，开始了Vulkan驱动程序的开发工作，并发布了PXE网络引导模式和USB大容量存储引导模式的原型-所有这些都伴随着通常的一轮错误修复、功能添加和内核版本颠簸。
虽然我们推出了1 GB、2 GB和4 GB的版本，但即使在那时，我们也看到了8 GB覆盆子PI 4的可能性。我们对这个想法非常热情，以至于这个不存在的产品同时出现在了入门指南和合规传单中。
我们在Raspberry PI 4上使用的BCM2711芯片可以寻址高达16 GB的LPDDR4 SDRAM，所以我们提供更大内存变体的真正障碍是缺乏8 GB的LPDDR4封装。这些在2019年并不存在(至少以我们可以解决的形式存在)，但幸运的是，我们在美光的合作伙伴在今年早些时候提供了一个合适的角色。因此，今天，我们很高兴地宣布，8 GB覆盆子PI 4即将上市，售价仅为75美元。
值得花点时间思考一下，8 GB的内存到底有多大。从回顾的角度来看，这是BBC Micro记忆中的每一点都相当于BBC Micro的内存；这是比尔·盖茨认为对任何人来说都应该足够的640KB的13000倍多一点(遗憾的是，这句话看起来似乎是杜撰的)。
如果您是一名高级用户，打算编译和链接大型软件或运行繁重的服务器工作负载，或者只是想要一次打开更多的浏览器标签，这绝对是最适合您的Raspberry PI。
为了提供新内存封装所需的稍高峰值电流，James调整了电路板上的电源组件，移除了电路板右侧USB 2.0插座旁边的开关模式电源，并在USB-C电源连接器旁边添加了一个新的开关。虽然这是一个必要的改变，但由于新冠肺炎中断了远东电感器的供应，我们最终损失了三个月的时间。
除此之外，这就是你逐渐了解和喜爱的那款覆盆子PI 4。
我们的默认操作系统映像使用32位LPAE内核和32位用户区域。这允许多个进程共享全部8 GB的内存，但受单个进程使用的内存不能超过3 GB的限制。对于大多数用户来说，这并不是一个严重的限制，特别是因为Chromium中的每个标签都有自己的进程。坚持使用32位用户空间的好处是，从2011年代的alpha板到今天闪亮的新8 GB产品，每一块主板上都可以运行相同的图像。
但是，想要将所有8 GB空间映射到单个进程的地址空间的高级用户需要一个64位的用户空间。市场上已经有很多选择，包括Ubuntu和Gentoo。
不用说，今天我们发布了我们自己的64位操作系统映像的早期测试版。它包含与您在常规32位映像中找到的相同的应用程序集和桌面环境，但它们是针对Debian arm64端口构建的。
我们的32位和64位操作系统映像都有一个新名称：Raspberry PI OS。随着我们社区的发展，我们希望确保新用户尽可能容易地找到我们推荐的Raspberry PI操作系统。我们认为新名称将帮助更多的人对使用我们的计算机和软件充满信心。针对我们所有操作系统映像的Raspberry Pi Desktop的更新也将于今天发布，我们将在明天的博客文章中对此进行更多的介绍。
你可以在这篇论坛帖子中找到新的64位图像的链接，以及一些重要的警告。
note_en:
Raspberry Pi 4 is  almost a year old, and it’s been a busy year. We’ve sold nearly 3 million units, shipped a couple of minor board revisions, and  reduced the price of the 2GB variant from $45 to $35. On the software side, we’ve done enormous amounts of work to  reduce the idle and loaded power consumption of the device,  passed OpenGL ES 3.1 conformance,  started work on a  Vulkan driver, and shipped PXE network boot mode and a  prototype of USB mass storage boot mode – all this alongside the usual round of bug fixes, feature additions, and kernel version bumps.
 While we launched with 1GB, 2GB and 4GB variants, even at that point we had our eye on the possibility of an 8GB Raspberry Pi 4. We were so enthusiastic about the idea that the non-existent product made its way into both the  Beginner’s Guide and the compliance leaflet.
  The BCM2711 chip that we use on Raspberry Pi 4 can address up to 16GB of LPDDR4 SDRAM, so the real barrier to our offering a larger-memory variant was the lack of an 8GB LPDDR4 package. These didn’t exist (at least in a form that we could address) in 2019, but happily our partners at Micron stepped up earlier this year with a suitable part. And so, today, we’re delighted to announce the  immediate availability of the  8GB Raspberry Pi 4, priced at just $75.
  It’s worth reflecting for a moment on what a vast quantity of memory 8GB really is. To put it in retro-perspective (retrospective?), this is a  BBC Micro‘s worth of memory for every  bit in the memory of the BBC Micro; it’s a little over 13,000 times the 640KB that Bill Gates supposedly thought should be enough for anyone (sadly, it looks as though this quote is  apocryphal).
 If you’re a power user, intending to compile and link large pieces of software or run heavy server workloads, or you simply want to be able to have even more browser tabs open at once, this is definitely the Raspberry Pi for you.
  To supply the slightly higher peak currents required by the new memory package, James has shuffled the power supply components on the board, removing a switch-mode power supply from the right-hand side of the board next to the USB 2.0 sockets and adding a new switcher next to the USB-C power connnector. While this was a necessary change, it ended up costing us a three-month slip, as COVID-19 disrupted the supply of inductors from the Far East.
  Other than that, this is the same Raspberry Pi 4 you’ve come to know and love.
  Our default  operating system image uses a 32-bit LPAE kernel and a 32-bit userland. This allows multiple processes to share all 8GB of memory, subject to the restriction that no single process can use more than 3GB. For most users this isn’t a serious restriction, particularly since every tab in Chromium gets its own process. Sticking with a 32-bit userland has the benefit that the same image will run on every board from a 2011-era  alpha board to today’s shiny new 8GB product.
 But power users, who want to be able to map all 8GB into the address space of a single process, need a 64-bit userland. There are plenty of options already out there, including  Ubuntu and  Gentoo.
 Not to be left out, today we’ve released an early beta of our own 64-bit operating system image. This contains the same set of applications and the same desktop environment that you’ll find in our regular 32-bit image, but built against the Debian arm64 port.
 Both our 32-bit and 64-bit operating system images have a new name: Raspberry Pi OS. As our community grows, we want to make sure it’s as easy as possible for new users to find our recommended operating system for Raspberry Pi. We think the new name will help more people feel confident in using our computers and our software. An update to the Raspberry Pi Desktop for all our operating system images is also out today, and we’ll have more on that in tomorrow’s blog post.
 You can find a link to the new 64-bit image, and some important caveats, in  this forum post.

I think the ability to find insights give individuals unique competitive advantages. As someone who wants to thrive in this world, I decided that I want to obtain insights, at least in software development (which is what I do for a living).
 To find insights, you need to think effectively. To think effectively, you must make your thinking tangible, so that you can look and see what’s ineffective. As far as I know, writings are the only tangible outcomes of thinking. Therefore I write a lot. However, writing is so difficult that, not all of my high-quality writings get published, and not all of my published writings are of high quality.
 When I write, I tend to read a lot of sources, oscillating between them as needed to compare and contrast ideas. After having some interesting thoughts, I will write them down. But such thoughts are often ostensible, or they hint at possibly new ways of interepreting existinng information. So I switch back to the sources to reconcile the new thoughts with them. This switching, when done frequently, feels unnecessary.
 What is lacking is a workspace where I can search for and read relevant sources without ever leaving the tab. I thought it would be fun and valuable to implement a simple writing workspace where you can drop in the source, search for, read relevant references, and write within the same workspace.  AWA is the result.
  For taking notes, I used  Roam Research obessively. However, Roam is a note-taking tool, and it’s not a writing workspace that serves the purpose of gathering sources and experiment with thoughts. On the opposite, you have to be mindful what to install into Roam, becaus it is designed to build a long-lasting repository , if you’re following the  Zettlkasten method.
 Another Writing Application is built as a place where you can dump your disorganized thoughts, organize them and then dump the organized thought into Roam or other places. In fact, I wrote this article using  AWA, with 7 references. It is not intended to replace anything, just an attempt in making writing, and consequently thinking, more convenient.
 Therefore, gathering sources, read, search for and experimental writing, all in the same place, is what  Another Writing Application is for.
    When you add an URL to  AWA, it calls the server to extract content using  Mercury Parser and insert that content into your local storage. The backend doesn’t store anything, it just returns the extracted content. As you read your sources for the first time, drop the URL into this and continue reading.
   When you have an interesting narrative, write it down. If you hit a term that summarizes a broad topic which you’re trying to articulate, search for that term.
 By default,  search-focus mode is used. Search-focus mode separates a given source into paragraph blocks, and only display the blocks that contain the searched term. You can expand other blocks to see the surrounding context.
  If you want even more broader context of the searched result, switch to  whole-text mode to see the entire text of the source.
   You can export the data in  json format. The exported file contains additional metadata extracted using Mercury Parser. Your writing will always has the ID  curren_note.
     But some would enjoy the sidebar on the left. You can change it either way. Please let me know which one you prefer more.
  Using  Marked to produce a HTML string from your writing and display it in the modal.
   See anything you don’t like ? Please feedback so that I can improve it. I use  SmtpJs to send the email, using my own email, so it is anonymous.
     I love Hyperapp by the way. It’s a minimalist approach to building web application. The concepts that you need to learn are way less than React and other front-end frameworks.
  I use  Agenda to keep my to-do and agenda. The entire process took me 6 days.
  There are bug fixes and features that I don’t explicitly add to the list, because I was in the flow.
       Somehow, my website on Github page is not styled exactly as what I see in my local development, while the version hosted on Netlify looks exactly the same.
   My backend is just a NodeJS application with Express, Cors (for local use) and  Mercury Parser as dependencies.
 Initially, I deployed the backend to Heroku. The deployment was really simple, which was good. However,  Heroku hibernates your app once in a while, and your app must sleep a certain amount of time within 3 days. In short, availability wasn’t guaranteed. Even though this is an open-sourced project and monetization isn’t the goal, I want it to be available. The unreliability of Heroku was a big demotivator for me, so I looked for an alternative.
 I looked into Netlifly cloud functions. However, there was  a limitation on the number of requests and number of running time. Then I thought that “free server hosting” was too broad a search phrase. My backend is a simple NodeJS-Express application. With that in mind, I looked into “free nodejs app hosting”, and after a bit of browsing, I stumbled across openode. It offers a free-tier for open-sourced projects. A quick google search did not reveal any limitation about availability, as least not so much that people would make such complaints available on Google search. I decided to go with openode.
  One thing I enjoyed about openode is that the deployment process is available through a commandline tool. Not too much up-front knowledge to be learnt for most NodeJS app developers. However, it wasn’t without friction.
   Building this application has really been an interesting challenge to me. I have had the opportunity to increase my problem solving, prototyping, time management skills, as well as how to use deliver an application from inception to delivery.

1983年夏天，斯坦福大学的一次研讨会成为从手工到代码漫长过渡过程中的一个里程碑。
1983年夏天，国际排字协会(ATypI)在加利福尼亚州的斯坦福大学举办了他们的第五次“工作研讨会”。它是一种会议形式，致力于研究、教育和讨论与排版和字体设计的最新技术发展有关的问题。该研讨会由Charles Bigelow主办，题目为“电脑与字体设计”，旨在展示字体制造中基于电脑的新可能性，以及切割和石雕等古老的模拟技能。约翰·德雷弗斯在三十年前见证了铁水铅字创立的终结，现在他觉得有必要在他的开幕式演讲中宣布“铅字设计的第二个转折点”。他提出了两个问题，希望在接下来的几天里找到答案：“现在需要什么样的字体设计？”以及“考虑到近年来的技术变化和现在创造印刷品的服务结构的变化，我们应该如何处理设计新型产品的问题？”
会议宣传册的封面图片(作者：Sumner Stone)展示了字体的清晰度和分辨率，从清晰的轮廓逐渐变成粗略的位图网格。小册子的内容体现了当时印刷界争论的一些问题，演讲者名单证明了冲床工人、计算机科学家、工程师以及领先的和新兴的设计师无懈可击的混合体。
加州斯坦福大学1983年ATypI工作研讨会的宣传册封面。萨姆纳·斯通的封面诠释了字体清晰度和分辨率的挑战-这在当时是一个反复出现的主题。上图：研讨会聚集了老牌和新兴的设计界人士。这张照片(以可视语言出版，第一卷。19，NO.1,1985)，显示(左至右)唐纳德·努斯，赫尔曼·扎普夫和约翰·德雷福斯在活动中。
在会议的开幕词中，德莱弗斯还表示，这次活动代表着工程师和设计师“为未来的字体设计合作”走到了一起。字体设计师长期以来一直严重依赖能用钢制字体的切割者，尽管这种关系从来都不是完全平等的，因为字体铸造厂往往不愿分享荣誉。然而，赫尔曼·扎普夫以他的拳击手而闻名，特别是奥古斯特·罗森伯格(1893-1980)，他切割了擎天柱等面孔。
Zapf的合作者Donald Knuth在他的演讲中表达了这样的愿望：“字母设计师与计算机科学家合作，就像他们过去与打孔机合作的方式一样”。在20世纪80年代，Zapf-Knuth二人组和Zapf-Rosenberger在20世纪50年代一样受欢迎，在这两种情况下，字体设计师都依赖另一半来实现他的字体。另一个这种合作的例子是剪纸大师大卫·金德斯利和计算机科学家尼尔·怀斯曼之间的合作，他们两人都在会议上发言。
辩论的核心是在研讨会上展示的五个所谓的字体设计系统，供设计师、教育工作者和管理层评估和发现新的可能性。他们创建数字字体的不同方法概括了复兴历史字体和创造新的原创设计之间的持久二分法。由Knuth(斯坦福，1979)和Elf by Wiseman(剑桥，1978)开发的Metafont系统将字母定义为“笔的路径”，可以有不同的粗细。当Metafont使用同名的编程语言通过某些参数描述字体时，Elf中的字母是通过沿路径构建梯形来生成的。
另一方面，Peter Karow的Ikarus(汉堡，1975)是一种类似于贝塞尔曲线的数字矢量格式，它通过所谓的“手数字化”，使用数字化平板和传感器来“追踪”模拟图形。Metafont和Elf配备了手绘和互动编辑功能，据说是设计新字体的理想选择；相比之下，Ikarus被认为是一种数字化工具，主要适用于复兴历史模型。
这个字体设计系统的环境还很小，但发展迅速，竞争激烈。在为数不多的几个会议评论之一中，in Fine Print(Vol.。10，NO.1,1984)，大卫·潘科报道了扎普夫和金德斯利之间关于梅塔丰和精灵各自成就的激烈辩论。
没有参加活动的人的名单和参加活动的人一样有趣。老牌字体制造商，如MonType型或LinType型，没有参加任何示范活动。但两年前与迈克·帕克(Mike Parker)共同创立Bitstream的马修·卡特(Matthew Carter)做了一次演讲。根据Charles Bigelow的说法，Bitstream是第一家全数字类型的铸造厂。根据卡特的说法，毕格罗是第一个使用“数码铸造厂”这个术语的人。有可能这个术语最早是在斯坦福研讨会上使用的。
一则轶事很好地说明了时代的挑战，美学的认知和对技术限制的处理。在一次没有在宣传册中公布的演讲中，萨姆纳·斯通展示了ATypI会议标识背后的设计过程。演示幻灯片展示了三种不同的试验，涉及钢笔素描、伊卡洛斯数字化、插值和不同阶段的“像素化”。在最近与我的通信中，斯通回忆说，在那次谈话之后，克努斯对他尝试了不同的设计方法感到“震惊”，他说他自己永远不会那样做，但会坚持一种方法，直到它奏效。
在随后的演讲中，努斯以斯通的标识为例，展示了它是如何使用Metafont创建的：“我们当然可以简单地勾画字母的轮廓；但这不会有任何乐趣，也不会给我们任何洞察力。”
斯坦福大学的演讲者名单揭示了一个多样化的聚会，从打孔师亨克·德罗斯特到计算机科学家尼尔·怀斯曼，从老牌排版师杰克·施陶法赫到新任命的查尔斯·毕格罗教授。布拉姆·德确实谈到了他的第一种字体Trinité。马修·卡特、维罗妮卡·埃尔斯纳和杰拉德·昂格是新一代“数码字体设计师”中的一员。图片来源：美国雷丁大学排版与图形传播系ATypI收藏品。
斯坦福大学1983年不是起点，而是漫长过渡过程中的一个里程碑。数字字体技术的早期可以被描述为一个独立解决方案的环境，非常类似于它之前的几十年的照片和金属字体，在那里，排字机仅限于特定设备可用的字体。然而，从1975年引入Ikarus开始，字体格式可以适应不同的设备，从而获得更大的灵活性。ATypI工作研讨会反映了这一过渡时期，但另一个更关键的转折点在前方。1985年，页面描述语言PostScript作为输入和输出设备之间的媒介，彻底改变了市场。尽管研讨会看起来是一场学者和专家的会议，但随着许多学生参加辩论，人们的看法发生了变化，随着新一代字体设计师的出现，一种“数字文化”开始出现。1983年在斯坦福大学讨论的许多问题在今天仍然有意义。
Eyes是世界上最漂亮、最具收藏价值的平面设计杂志，每季度出版一次，面向专业设计师、学生和任何对有关平面设计和视觉文化的批判性、见多识广的写作感兴趣的人。它可以在所有优秀的设计书店购买，也可以在Eye商店在线购买，在那里你可以购买订阅、过刊和最新一期的单本。在Vimeo上购买之前，你可以在Eye上看到Eye 94的样子。

In the summer of 1983, a Stanford seminar became a milestone in the long transition from craft to code
  In the summer of 1983 the Association Typographique Internationale (ATypI) hosted their fifth ‘Working Seminar’ at Stanford University in California. It was a conference format dedicated to research, education and discourse related to the latest technological developments in typography and type design. Organised by Charles Bigelow, the seminar – under the title ‘The Computer and the Hand in Type Design’ – was aimed at demonstrating new computer-based possibilities in type manufacturing, but also the older analogue skills of cutting and stone-carving. Having witnessed the end of hot-metal type-founding three decades earlier, John Dreyfus felt compelled now to proclaim a ‘second turning-point in type design’ in his opening lecture. He raised two questions, hoping to find answers in the following days: ‘What kinds of type designs are needed now?’ and ‘How ought we to approach the problems of designing new types, taking into account the technical changes of recent years and the altered structure of the services which now create printed matter?’
 The conference brochure’s cover image (by Sumner Stone) is a demonstration of letterform definition and resolution, graduating from a crisp outline to a coarse grid of bitmaps. The contents of the brochure embody some of the issues debated within typographic communities at the time, and the list of speakers gives evidence of an impeccable medley of punchcutters, computer scientists, engineers plus leading and emerging type designers.
  Cover of the brochure announcing the 1983 ATypI working seminar at Stanford  University in California. Sumner Stone’s cover interprets the challenges of letterform definition and resolution – a recurring theme at the time. 	Top:  The seminar assembled established and emerging     type design personalities. This photo (published in  Visible Language, vol. 19, no. 1, 1985), shows (L to R) Donald Knuth, Hermann Zapf and John Dreyfus at the event.
  In his opening remarks at the conference, Dreyfus also suggested that the event represented the coming together of engineers and designers ‘for future cooperation in type design’. Type designers had long relied heavily on cutters who could cut letterforms in steel, though this relationship was never entirely equal, with type foundries often reluctant to share credit. However Hermann Zapf was known for crediting his punchcutters, particularly August Rosenberger (1893-1980), who cut Optima, among other faces.
 Zapf’s collaborator Donald Knuth, in his talk, expressed the wish that ‘letter designers team up with computer scientists the way they used to collaborate with punchcutters’. In the 1980s the Zapf-Knuth duo was as popular as Zapf-Rosenberger had been in the 1950s, and in both cases the type designer depended on the other half to realise his letterforms. Another example of such a collaboration is that between the lettercutter David Kindersley and the computer scientist Neil Wiseman, both of whom spoke at the conference.
 At the heart of the debate were five so-called type design systems presented at the seminar, for evaluation and discovery of new possibilities by designers, educators and management. Their different approaches to creating digital fonts encapsulate an enduring dichotomy between reviving historical typefaces and creating new original designs. The systems Metafont, developed by Knuth (Stanford, 1979) and Elf by Wiseman (Cambridge, 1978) defined letters in terms of ‘the path of a pen’ that could have different thicknesses. While Metafont described letterforms through certain parameters, using a programming language of the same name, letters in Elf were generated by building trapeziums along the path.
 Ikarus by Peter Karow (Hamburg, 1975), on the other hand, was a digital vector format similar to that of Bézier curves, which worked through what was called ‘hand-digitisation’, using a digitising tablet and a sensor to ‘trace’ analogue drawings. Equipped with free-hand drawing and interactive editing features, Metafont and Elf were said to be ideal for the design of new letterforms; Ikarus, by contrast, was conceived as a digitising tool appropriate mostly for reviving historical models.
 This environment of type design systems was still small, yet rapidly growing and competitive. In one of the few conference reviews, in Fine Print (vol. 10, no. 1, 1984), David Pankow reports a heated debate between Zapf and Kindersley over the respective achievements of Metafont and Elf.
 The list of those who did not attend the event is as interesting as those who did. Established font manufacturers such as Monotype or Linotype did not participate in any of the demonstrations. But Matthew Carter, who had co-founded Bitstream with Mike Parker two years earlier, gave a talk. According to Charles Bigelow, Bitstream was the first all-digital type foundry. According to Carter, Bigelow was the first to use the term ‘digital type foundry’. It is possible that the term was first used at the Stanford seminar.
 One anecdote says a lot about the challenges of the time, the perception of aesthetics and the handling of technological limitations. In a talk that was not announced in the brochure, Sumner Stone demonstrated the design process behind the ATypI conference logotype. The presentation slides show three different trials, involving pen sketches, Ikarus digitisation, interpolations, and ‘pixelisation’ in various stages. In recent correspondence with me, Stone recalled that, after the talk, Knuth was ‘shocked’ that he had tried different design approaches, saying that he himself would never do that, but would stick with one approach until it worked.
 In his own lecture afterwards, Knuth took Stone’s logotype as an example, showing how it could have been created using Metafont: ‘Of course we could simply trace the outlines of the letters; but that would not be any fun, and it would not give us any insights.’
  The Stanford speakers’ list reveals a diverse gathering, from punchcutter Henk Drost to computer scientist Neil Wiseman; from established typographer Jack Stauffacher to newly appointed professor Charles Bigelow. Bram de Does spoke about his first typeface Trinité. Matthew Carter, Veronika Elsner and Gerard Unger were part of a new generation of ‘digital type designers’. Image: ATypI collection of the University of Reading, Department of Typography and Graphic Communication.
  Stanford 1983 was not the starting point, but a milestone in a long transition. The early years of digital type technology can be described as an environment of stand-alone solutions, very much like the decades of photo and metal type before it, where the typesetter was limited to the typefaces available for a particular device. However, beginning with the introduction of Ikarus in 1975, font formats could be adapted to a different devices, allowing for more flexibility. The ATypI working seminar reflects this period of transition, but another much more crucial turning-point lay ahead. In 1985, the page description language PostScript, a mediator between input and output devices, completely changed the market. Although the seminar appears to have been a meeting of academics and specialists, the perception shifted as many students attended the debates and, with a new generation of type designers, a ‘digital culture’ began to emerge. Many of the issues discussed at Stanford in 1983 are still relevant today.
